title: How do management decisions impact butterfly assemblages in smallholding oil palm plantations in Peninsular Malaysia?
content:
Our findings suggest that replanting oil palm and choice of mono or polyculture have relatively few effects on butterflies, but management for specific features in plantations could benefit butterfly assemblages.


Abstract

In the world's leading palm oil-producing countries (Indonesia and Malaysia), smallholders make up about 40 per cent of total oil palm plantation area. Management in smallholdings can be highly variable, ranging from intensive monoculture to polyculture systems, especially in the earlier years of cultivation when open canopies allow a variety of understorey crop types to be grown alongside oil palm. Currently, many plantations in the region are mature and due to be replanted, which is likely to have substantial impacts on the ecosystems within them, but studies investigating the impacts of alternative post-replanting management strategies in smallholder plantations are lacking. We investigated the impacts of replanting and choice of crop management following replanting (growing oil palm as a monoculture or polyculture) on habitat structure and complexity, and on the abundance, richness and composition of butterfly assemblages in smallholding oil palm plantations in Banting, Selangor, Malaysia. We also assessed the direct effects of habitat structure and complexity on butterfly assemblages. Butterflies are likely to be a valuable indicator group for monitoring the impacts of management practices on biodiversity as butterfly species also show a range of sensitivities to habitat disturbance, with some being vulnerable to change, but others being common in plantations. They are also a functionally important group that pollinate wild plants, are prey for larger species and are common in tropical systems. Across 27 plantations, we recorded 1227 butterflies from 5 families, 46 genera and 56 species. Habitat structure and complexity differed between management decisions (mature monoculture, immature monoculture, immature polyculture), although many environmental parameters overlapped. We found no significant differences in species richness, density and assemblage composition of butterflies between management decisions. However, changes in local environmental conditions, such as an increase in the coverage of understorey vegetation, increased the abundance of butterflies. Synthesis and applications. Our findings suggest that replanting oil palm and choice of mono or polyculture have relatively few effects on butterflies, but management for specific features in plantations could benefit butterfly assemblages.

Abstrak

Di negara pengeluar minyak sawit terkemuka dunia (Indonesia dan Malaysia), pekebun kecil menyumbang kira-kira 40 peratus daripada jumlah keseluruhan kawasan tanaman kelapa sawit. Pengurusan di ladang pekebun kecil adalah pelbagai, merangkumi monokultur intensif dan polikultur, terutamanya pada peringkat awal penanaman di mana kanopi pokok sawit masih terbuka dan membolehkan pelbagai jenis tanaman kontan ditanam bersama kelapa sawit. Pada masa sekarang, banyak ladang sawit pekebun kecil telah mencapai tahap yang tidak ekonomik dan perlu ditanam semula. Proses penanaman semula berkemungkinan besar akan menjejaskan ekosistem di dalam ladang kelapa sawit dan kajian mengenai impak pengurusan pasca tanam semula di ladang sawit pekebun kecil adalah masih kurang. Kami mengkaji kesan penanaman semula dan pemilihan pengurusan tanaman selepas penanaman semula (menanam kelapa sawit sebagai monokultur atau polikultur) terhadap struktur dan kekompleksan habitat, kelimpahan, kekayaan, dan komposisi kumpulan kupu-kupu di ladang kelapa sawit pekebun kecil di Banting, Selangor, Malaysia. Kami juga menilai kesan langsung struktur dan kekompleksan habitat pada kumpulan kupu-kupu. Kupu-kupu berperanan sebagai penunjuk biologi yang berharga untuk memantau kesan amalan pengurusan ladang pada biodiversiti kerana spesies kupu-kupu menunjukkan pelbagai sensitiviti terhadap gangguan habitat, dengan sesetengahnya terkesan, dan terdapat juga spesis yang dapat beradaptasi. Selain itu, kupu-kupu juga berperanan dalam pendebungaan tumbuhan liar, dan menjadi sumber makanan untuk spesies yang lebih besar, serta merupakan serangga yang biasa ditemui di dalam ekosistem tropika. Daripada 27 ladang, kami merekodkan 1227 ekor kupu-kupu yang terdiri daripada 5 famili, 46 genera dan 56 spesies. Struktur dan kekompleksan habitat berbeza antara keputusan pengurusan (monokultur matang, monokultur belum matang, polikultur belum matang), walaupun banyak parameter persekitaran bertindih. Kami tidak menemui perbezaan yang signifikan dalam kekayaan spesies, kepadatan, dan komposisi kumpulan kupu-kupu antara keputusan pengurusan. Walau bagaimanapun, perubahan dalam keadaan persekitaran tempatan, seperti peningkatan liputan tumbuhan lapisan bawah, dapat meningkatkan kelimpahan kupu-kupu. Sintesis dan aplikasi. Penemuan kami mencadangkan bahawa penanaman semula kelapa sawit dan pemilihan kaedah penanaman monokultur atau polikultur mempunyai kesan yang agak sedikit terhadap kupu-kupu, Walau bagaimanapun pengurusan untuk ciri-ciri tertentu dalam ladang boleh memberi manfaat kepada kumpulan kupu-kupu.
